trans-unit.source: Create and use a SAS with the Blob Service | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create and use a SAS with the Blob Service | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Explore generating and using shared access signatures with the Blob service
trans-unit.target: Explore generating and using shared access signatures with the Blob service

trans-unit.source: Shared Access Signatures, Part 2: Create and Use a SAS with the Blob Service
trans-unit.target: Shared Access Signatures, Part 2: Create and Use a SAS with the Blob Service

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Part 1</linkText><title></title></link> of this tutorial explored shared access signatures (SAS) and explained best practices for using them.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Part 1</linkText><title></title></link> of this tutorial explored shared access signatures (SAS) and explained best practices for using them.

trans-unit.source: Part 2 shows you how to generate and then use shared access signatures with the Azure Blob service.
trans-unit.target: Part 2 shows you how to generate and then use shared access signatures with the Azure Blob service.

trans-unit.source: The examples are written in C# and use the Azure Storage Client Library for .NET.
trans-unit.target: The examples are written in C# and use the Azure Storage Client Library for .NET.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include these aspects of working with shared access signatures:
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include these aspects of working with shared access signatures:

trans-unit.source: Generating a shared access signature on a container
trans-unit.target: Generating a shared access signature on a container

trans-unit.source: Generating a shared access signature on a blob
trans-unit.target: Generating a shared access signature on a blob

trans-unit.source: Creating a stored access policy to manage signatures on a container's resources
trans-unit.target: Creating a stored access policy to manage signatures on a container's resources

trans-unit.source: Testing the shared access signatures from a client application
trans-unit.target: Testing the shared access signatures from a client application

trans-unit.source: About this Tutorial
trans-unit.target: About this Tutorial

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we'll focus on creating shared access signatures for containers and blobs by creating two console applications.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we'll focus on creating shared access signatures for containers and blobs by creating two console applications.

trans-unit.source: The first console application generates shared access signatures on a container and on a blob.
trans-unit.target: The first console application generates shared access signatures on a container and on a blob.

trans-unit.source: This application has knowledge of the storage account keys.
trans-unit.target: This application has knowledge of the storage account keys.

trans-unit.source: The second console application, which will act as a client application, accesses container and blob resources using the shared access signatures created with the first application.
trans-unit.target: The second console application, which will act as a client application, accesses container and blob resources using the shared access signatures created with the first application.

trans-unit.source: This application uses the shared access signatures only to authenticate its access to the container and blob resources - it does not have knowledge of the account keys.
trans-unit.target: This application uses the shared access signatures only to authenticate its access to the container and blob resources - it does not have knowledge of the account keys.

trans-unit.source: Part 1: Create a Console Application to Generate Shared Access Signatures
trans-unit.target: Part 1: Create a Console Application to Generate Shared Access Signatures

trans-unit.source: First, ensure that you have the Azure Storage Client Library for .NET installed.
trans-unit.target: First, ensure that you have the Azure Storage Client Library for .NET installed.

trans-unit.source: You can install the <link><linkText>NuGet package</linkText><title>NuGet package</title></link> containing the most up-to-date assemblies for the client library; this is the recommended method for ensuring that you have the most recent fixes.
trans-unit.target: You can install the <link><linkText>NuGet package</linkText><title>NuGet package</title></link> containing the most up-to-date assemblies for the client library; this is the recommended method for ensuring that you have the most recent fixes.

trans-unit.source: You can also download the client library as part of the most recent version of the <link><linkText>Azure SDK for .NET</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can also download the client library as part of the most recent version of the <link><linkText>Azure SDK for .NET</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, create a new Windows console application and name it GenerateSharedAccessSignatures.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, create a new Windows console application and name it GenerateSharedAccessSignatures.

trans-unit.source: Add references to Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Configuration.dll and Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.dll, using either of the following approaches:
trans-unit.target: Add references to Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Configuration.dll and Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.dll, using either of the following approaches:

trans-unit.source: If you want to install the NuGet package, first install the <link><linkText>NuGet Package Manager Extension for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to install the NuGet package, first install the <link><linkText>NuGet Package Manager Extension for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, select Project | Manage NuGet Packages, search online for Azure Storage, and follow the instructions to install.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, select Project | Manage NuGet Packages, search online for Azure Storage, and follow the instructions to install.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, locate the assemblies in your installation of the Azure SDK and add references to them.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, locate the assemblies in your installation of the Azure SDK and add references to them.

trans-unit.source: At the top of the Program.cs file, add the following using statements:
trans-unit.target: At the top of the Program.cs file, add the following using statements:

trans-unit.source: Edit the app.config file so that it contains a configuration setting with a connection string that points to your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Edit the app.config file so that it contains a configuration setting with a connection string that points to your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Your app.config file should look similar to this one:
trans-unit.target: Your app.config file should look similar to this one:

trans-unit.source: Generate a Shared Access Signature URI for a Container
trans-unit.target: Generate a Shared Access Signature URI for a Container

trans-unit.source: To begin with, we'll add a method to generate a shared access signature on a new container.
trans-unit.target: To begin with, we'll add a method to generate a shared access signature on a new container.

trans-unit.source: In this case the signature is not associated with a stored access policy, so it carries on the URI the information indicating its expiry time and the permissions that it grants.
trans-unit.target: In this case the signature is not associated with a stored access policy, so it carries on the URI the information indicating its expiry time and the permissions that it grants.

trans-unit.source: First, add code to the Main() method to authenticate access to your storage account and create a new container:
trans-unit.target: First, add code to the Main() method to authenticate access to your storage account and create a new container:

trans-unit.source: Next, add a new method that generates the shared access signature for the container and returns the signature URI:
trans-unit.target: Next, add a new method that generates the shared access signature for the container and returns the signature URI:

trans-unit.source: Add the following lines at the bottom of the Main() method, before the call to Console.ReadLine(), to call GetContainerSasUri() and write the signature URI to the console window:
trans-unit.target: Add the following lines at the bottom of the Main() method, before the call to Console.ReadLine(), to call GetContainerSasUri() and write the signature URI to the console window:

trans-unit.source: Compile and run to output the shared access signature URI for the new container.
trans-unit.target: Compile and run to output the shared access signature URI for the new container.

trans-unit.source: The URI will be similar to the following URI:
trans-unit.target: The URI will be similar to the following URI:

trans-unit.source: Once you have run the code, the shared access signature that you created on the container will be valid for the next twenty-four hours.
trans-unit.target: Once you have run the code, the shared access signature that you created on the container will be valid for the next twenty-four hours.

trans-unit.source: The signature grants a client permission to list blobs in the container and to write a new blob to the container.
trans-unit.target: The signature grants a client permission to list blobs in the container and to write a new blob to the container.

trans-unit.source: Generate a Shared Access Signature URI for a Blob
trans-unit.target: Generate a Shared Access Signature URI for a Blob

trans-unit.source: Next, we'll write similar code to create a new blob within the container and generate a shared access signature for it.
trans-unit.target: Next, we'll write similar code to create a new blob within the container and generate a shared access signature for it.

trans-unit.source: This shared access signature is not associated with a stored access policy, so it includes the start time, expiry time, and permission information on the URI.
trans-unit.target: This shared access signature is not associated with a stored access policy, so it includes the start time, expiry time, and permission information on the URI.

trans-unit.source: Add a new method that creates a new blob and write some text to it, then generates a shared access signature and returns the signature URI:
trans-unit.target: Add a new method that creates a new blob and write some text to it, then generates a shared access signature and returns the signature URI:

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the Main() method, add the following lines to call GetBlobSasUri(), before the call to Console.ReadLine(), and write the shared access signature URI to the console window:
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the Main() method, add the following lines to call GetBlobSasUri(), before the call to Console.ReadLine(), and write the shared access signature URI to the console window:

trans-unit.source: Compile and run to output the shared access signature URI for the new blob.
trans-unit.target: Compile and run to output the shared access signature URI for the new blob.

trans-unit.source: The URI will be similar to the following URI:
trans-unit.target: The URI will be similar to the following URI:

trans-unit.source: Create a Stored Access Policy on the Container
trans-unit.target: Create a Stored Access Policy on the Container

trans-unit.source: Now let's create a stored access policy on the container, which will define the constraints for any shared access signatures that are associated with it.
trans-unit.target: Now let's create a stored access policy on the container, which will define the constraints for any shared access signatures that are associated with it.

trans-unit.source: In the previous examples, we specified the start time (implicitly or explicitly), the expiry time, and the permissions on the shared access signature URI itself.
trans-unit.target: In the previous examples, we specified the start time (implicitly or explicitly), the expiry time, and the permissions on the shared access signature URI itself.

trans-unit.source: In the following examples, we will specify these on the stored access policy and not on the shared access signature.
trans-unit.target: In the following examples, we will specify these on the stored access policy and not on the shared access signature.

trans-unit.source: Doing so enables us to change these constraints without reissuing the shared access signature.
trans-unit.target: Doing so enables us to change these constraints without reissuing the shared access signature.

trans-unit.source: It's possible to have one or more of the constraints on the shared access signature and the remainder on the stored access policy.
trans-unit.target: It's possible to have one or more of the constraints on the shared access signature and the remainder on the stored access policy.

trans-unit.source: However, you can only specify the start time, expiry time, and permissions in one place or the other; for example, you can't specify permissions on the shared access signature and also specify them on the stored access policy.
trans-unit.target: However, you can only specify the start time, expiry time, and permissions in one place or the other; for example, you can't specify permissions on the shared access signature and also specify them on the stored access policy.

trans-unit.source: Note that when you add an access policy to a container, you must get the container's existing permissions, add the new access policy, and then set the container's permissions.
trans-unit.target: Note that when you add an access policy to a container, you must get the container's existing permissions, add the new access policy, and then set the container's permissions.

trans-unit.source: Add a new method that creates a new stored access policy on a container and returns the name of the policy:
trans-unit.target: Add a new method that creates a new stored access policy on a container and returns the name of the policy:

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the Main() method, before the call to Console.ReadLine(), add the following lines to first clear any existing access policies and then call the CreateSharedAccessPolicy() method:
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the Main() method, before the call to Console.ReadLine(), add the following lines to first clear any existing access policies and then call the CreateSharedAccessPolicy() method:

trans-unit.source: Note that when you clear the access policies on a container, you must first get the container's existing permissions, then clear the permissions, then set the permissions again.
trans-unit.target: Note that when you clear the access policies on a container, you must first get the container's existing permissions, then clear the permissions, then set the permissions again.

trans-unit.source: Generate a Shared Access Signature URI on the Container That Uses an Access Policy
trans-unit.target: Generate a Shared Access Signature URI on the Container That Uses an Access Policy

trans-unit.source: Next, we'll create another shared access signature on the container that we created earlier, but this time we'll associate the signature with the access policy that we created in the previous example.
trans-unit.target: Next, we'll create another shared access signature on the container that we created earlier, but this time we'll associate the signature with the access policy that we created in the previous example.

trans-unit.source: Add a new method to generate another shared access signature on the container:
trans-unit.target: Add a new method to generate another shared access signature on the container:

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the Main() method, before the call to Console.ReadLine(), add the following lines to call the GetContainerSasUriWithPolicy method:
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the Main() method, before the call to Console.ReadLine(), add the following lines to call the GetContainerSasUriWithPolicy method:

trans-unit.source: Generate a Shared Access Signature URI on the Blob That Uses an Access Policy
trans-unit.target: Generate a Shared Access Signature URI on the Blob That Uses an Access Policy

trans-unit.source: Finally, we'll add a similar method to create another blob and generate a shared access signature that's associated with an access policy.
trans-unit.target: Finally, we'll add a similar method to create another blob and generate a shared access signature that's associated with an access policy.

trans-unit.source: Add a new method to create a blob and generate a shared access signature:
trans-unit.target: Add a new method to create a blob and generate a shared access signature:

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the Main() method, before the call to Console.ReadLine(), add the following lines to call the GetBlobSasUriWithPolicy method:
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the Main() method, before the call to Console.ReadLine(), add the following lines to call the GetBlobSasUriWithPolicy method:

trans-unit.source: The Main() method should now look like this in its entirety.
trans-unit.target: The Main() method should now look like this in its entirety.

trans-unit.source: Run it to write the shared access signature URIs to the console window, then copy and paste them into a text file for use in the second part of this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Run it to write the shared access signature URIs to the console window, then copy and paste them into a text file for use in the second part of this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: When you run the GenerateSharedAccessSignatures console application, you'll see output similar to the following in the console window.
trans-unit.target: When you run the GenerateSharedAccessSignatures console application, you'll see output similar to the following in the console window.

trans-unit.source: These are the shared access signatures that you'll use in Part 2 of the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: These are the shared access signatures that you'll use in Part 2 of the tutorial.

trans-unit.target: <linkText>sas-console-output-1</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Part 2: Create a Console Application to Test the Shared Access Signatures
trans-unit.target: Part 2: Create a Console Application to Test the Shared Access Signatures

trans-unit.source: To test the shared access signatures created in the previous examples, we'll create a second console application that uses the signatures to perform operations on the container and on a blob.
trans-unit.target: To test the shared access signatures created in the previous examples, we'll create a second console application that uses the signatures to perform operations on the container and on a blob.

trans-unit.source: If more than 24 hours have passed since you completed the first part of the tutorial, the signatures you generated will no longer be valid.
trans-unit.target: If more than 24 hours have passed since you completed the first part of the tutorial, the signatures you generated will no longer be valid.

trans-unit.source: In this case, you should run the code in the first console application to generate fresh shared access signatures for use in the second part of the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In this case, you should run the code in the first console application to generate fresh shared access signatures for use in the second part of the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, create a new Windows console application and name it ConsumeSharedAccessSignatures.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, create a new Windows console application and name it ConsumeSharedAccessSignatures.

trans-unit.source: Add references to Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Configuration.dll and Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.dll, as you did previously.
trans-unit.target: Add references to Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Configuration.dll and Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.dll, as you did previously.

trans-unit.source: At the top of the Program.cs file, add the following using statements:
trans-unit.target: At the top of the Program.cs file, add the following using statements:

trans-unit.source: In the body of the Main() method, add the following constants, and update their values to the shared access signatures that you generated in part 1 of the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In the body of the Main() method, add the following constants, and update their values to the shared access signatures that you generated in part 1 of the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Add a Method to Try Container Operations Using a Shared Access Signature
trans-unit.target: Add a Method to Try Container Operations Using a Shared Access Signature

trans-unit.source: Next, we'll add a method that tests some representative container operations using a shared access signature on the container.
trans-unit.target: Next, we'll add a method that tests some representative container operations using a shared access signature on the container.

trans-unit.source: Note that the shared access signature is used to return a reference to the container, authenticating access to the container based on the signature alone.
trans-unit.target: Note that the shared access signature is used to return a reference to the container, authenticating access to the container based on the signature alone.

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to Program.cs:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to Program.cs:

trans-unit.source: Update the Main() method to call UseContainerSAS() with both of the shared access signatures that you created on the container:
trans-unit.target: Update the Main() method to call UseContainerSAS() with both of the shared access signatures that you created on the container:

trans-unit.source: Add a Method to Try Blob Operations Using a Shared Access Signature
trans-unit.target: Add a Method to Try Blob Operations Using a Shared Access Signature

trans-unit.source: Finally, we'll add a method that tests some representative blob operations using a shared access signature on the blob.
trans-unit.target: Finally, we'll add a method that tests some representative blob operations using a shared access signature on the blob.

trans-unit.source: In this case we use the constructor CloudBlockBlob(String), passing in the shared access signature, to return a reference to the blob.
trans-unit.target: In this case we use the constructor CloudBlockBlob(String), passing in the shared access signature, to return a reference to the blob.

trans-unit.source: No other authentication is required; it's based on the signature alone.
trans-unit.target: No other authentication is required; it's based on the signature alone.

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to Program.cs:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to Program.cs:

trans-unit.source: Update the Main() method to call UseBlobSAS() with both of the shared access signatures that you created on the blob:
trans-unit.target: Update the Main() method to call UseBlobSAS() with both of the shared access signatures that you created on the blob:

trans-unit.source: Run the console application and observe the output to see which operations are permitted for which signatures.
trans-unit.target: Run the console application and observe the output to see which operations are permitted for which signatures.

trans-unit.source: The output in the console window will look similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: The output in the console window will look similar to the following:
